post.author: nasa
post.title:
The Moon in all of its celestial glory. ‚ú®
 
A full Moon is pictured above Earth‚Äôs horizon as the International Space Station (ISS) orbited 263 miles (423 kilometers) above the Washington-Oregon border in the northwestern United States. 
 
This weekend, you may be able to witness what some call the Pink Moon. Named after the herb moss pink, also known as creeping phlox, it‚Äôs one of the earliest widespread flowers of spring in the eastern United States.
 
Pencil in some lunar admiration this weekend, as the full Moon will be visible through Sunday. Go to moon.nasa.gov and click the ‚ÄúObserve‚Äù tab for viewing and photography tips.
 
Credit: NASA
 
#NASA #Moon #Moonlight #FullMoon #Lunar #Nightsky #Skywatching #InternationalSpaceStation #ISS #MoonPhotography #Luna

post.author: nasa
post.title:
Psst. Wanna see a total lunar eclipse? üåûüåéüåóOn May 15, Earth will pass between the Sun and the Moon, blocking sunlight and casting a shadow on the lunar surface. The result: a Moon that looks like it's blushing because everybody is gawking at it.Starting at 9:32 p.m. EDT (1:32 UTC on May 16), people with clear skies in the Americas, Europe, and parts of Africa will begin to see the Moon get bathed in the red glow of every sunrise and sunset refracted through Earth‚Äôs atmosphere. Totality will occur at 12:12 a.m. EDT on May 16 (4:12 UTC).What if it's cloudy where you are? We're livestreaming the eclipse from locations across the planet. We're also hosting an episode of "NASA Science Live from 11 p.m. - midnight EDT (03:00 - 04:00 UTC) with NASA experts. Go to moon.nasa.gov for details.

Credit: NASA#LunarEclipse #TotalEclipse #TotalLunarEclipse #Eclipse #Moon #Luna #Science #Astronomy #NASA

post.author: nasa
post.title:
Hi-diddly-ho, neighborino! üëã‚Å£
‚Å£
Our neighbor in space, the immense Andromeda galaxy, is captured in this image taken by the Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer (WISE). Located about 2.5 million light-years from our Sun, Andromeda is the closest large galaxy to our Milky Way galaxy.‚Å£
‚Å£
This galactic mosaic is a four-color composite using all of WISE‚Äôs infrared detectors, where blue represents far-ultraviolet light, green represents mid-way ultraviolet light, and red is near-ultraviolet light. The galaxy's backbone of mature stars is visible in blue, while the yellow and red rings show dust heated by newborn, massive stars.‚Å£
‚Å£
Both the Milky Way and Andromeda galaxies belong to our so-called Local Group, a collection of more than 50 galaxies, which is like our ‚Äúgalactic neighborhood‚Äù; however, most of the other galaxies are tiny dwarf systems.‚Å£
‚Å£
Credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech/UCLA‚Å£
‚Å£
#NASA #Space #Galaxies #Galaxy #Stars #Astrophotography #Andromeda #MilkyWay #Astronomy

post.author: nasa
post.title:
Here it is: the grand finale of the James Webb Space Telescope‚Äôs first images.‚Å£‚Å£
 ‚Å£‚Å£
Behind the curtain of dust and gas in these ‚ÄúCosmic Cliffs‚Äù are previously hidden baby stars, now uncovered by the Webb telescope. Take a second to admire the Carina Nebula in all its glory.‚Å£‚Å£
 ‚Å£‚Å£
Webb‚Äôs new view gives us a rare peek into stars in their earliest, rapid stages of formation. For an individual star, this period only lasts about 50,000 to 100,000 years.‚Å£‚Å£
 ‚Å£‚Å£
View and download the full image of Webb‚Äôs ‚ÄúCosmic Cliffs‚Äù at the link in our bio: nasa.gov/webbfirstimages ‚Å£‚Å£
 
Alt text:‚Å£‚Å£ The image is divided horizontally by an undulating line between a cloudscape forming a nebula along the bottom portion and a comparatively clear upper portion. Speckled across both portions is a starfield, showing innumerable stars of many sizes. The smallest of these are small, distant, and faint points of light. The largest of these appear larger, closer, brighter, and more fully resolved with 8-point diffraction spikes. The upper portion of the image is blueish, and has wispy translucent cloud-like streaks rising from the nebula below. The orangish cloudy formation in the bottom half varies in density and ranges from translucent to opaque. The stars vary in color, the majority of which, have a blue or orange hue. The cloud-like structure of the nebula contains ridges, peaks, and valleys ‚Äì an appearance very similar to a mountain range. Three long diffraction spikes from the top right edge of the image suggest the presence of a large star just out of view.‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
Credits: NASA, ESA, CSA, and STScI‚Å£‚Å£
 ‚Å£‚Å£
#UnfoldTheUniverse #NASA #Space #NASAWebb #ESAWebb #Webb #JWST #SpaceTelescope #JamesWebbSpaceTelescope #stars #nebula

post.author: nasa
post.title:
Giant news from a giant planet! üì∞

NASAWebb captured a new view of Jupiter in infrared light, uncovering clues to the planet‚Äôs inner life in a new image. In addition to the planet‚Äôs iconic Great Red Spot, two of its moons, rings, and even distant galaxies are visible.

Since infrared light is invisible to humans, the light has been mapped onto the visible spectrum. Generally, the longest wavelengths appear redder and the shortest wavelengths are shown as more blue.

Citizen scientist Judy Schmidt processed these images and turned the raw data collected from Webb's sensors into the visual you see here.

Image Description 1: Jupiter dominates the black background of space. The image is a composite, and shows Jupiter in enhanced color. The planet‚Äôs Great Red Spot appears white here. The planet is striated with swirling horizontal stripes of neon turquoise, periwinkle, light pink, and cream. The stripes interact and mix at their edges like cream in coffee. Along both of the poles, the planet glows in turquoise. Bright orange auroras glow just above the planet‚Äôs surface at both poles.

Image Description 2: A wide field view showcases Jupiter in the upper right quadrant. The planet‚Äôs swirling horizontal stripes are rendered in blues, browns, and cream. Electric blue auroras glow above Jupiter‚Äôs north and south poles. A white glow emanates out from the auroras. Along the planet‚Äôs equator, rings glow in a faint white. These rings are one million times fainter than the planet itself! At the far left edge of the rings, a moon appears as a tiny white dot. This moon is only about 12 miles (20 km) across. Slightly further to the left, another moon, about 100 miles (150 km) across, glows with tiny white diffraction spikes. The rest of the image is the blackness of space, with faintly glowing white galaxies in the distance.

Credit 1: NASA, ESA, CSA, Jupiter ERS Team; image processing by Judy Schmidt.

Credit 2: NASA, ESA, CSA, Jupiter ERS Team; image processing by Ricardo Hueso (UPV/EHU) and Judy Schmidt.

#NASA #JWST #Webb #Astrophotography #Jupiter #Space #SolarSystem #CitizenScience #Planet

post.author: nasa
post.title:
At 7:14 p.m. EDT (23:14 UTC), our #DartMission successfully impacted its target, non-hazardous asteroid Dimorphos, in the world‚Äôs first planetary defense mission.‚Å£
‚Å£
The Double Asteroid Redirection Test (DART) aims to demonstrate that the path of an asteroid can be changed using a kinetic impactor. A vending machine-size spacecraft deliberately crashed into a stadium-size asteroid at 14,000 mph (22,500 km/h).‚Å£
‚Å£
This test hopes to show that kinetic impact is a viable technology that could be deployed someday to prevent an asteroid from hitting the Earth, should one be discovered. There are no known asteroid threats to Earth for at least the next 100 years.‚Å£
‚Å£
1. The final 5.5 minutes leading the intentional collision with asteroid Dimorphos. This video is 10x faster than reality, except for the last six images, which are shown at the same rate that the spacecraft returned them. Both Didymos and its moonlet Dimorphos are visible at the start.  At the end, Dimorphos fills the field of view. DART‚Äôs impact occurred during transmission of the final image to Earth, resulting in a partial picture at the end of this movie.‚Å£
‚Å£
2. Asteroid Didymos (bottom left) and its moonlet, Dimorphos (center), about 2.5 minutes before DART impact. The DRACO imager captured this image from a distance of 570 miles (920 km). This image was the last to contain a complete view of both asteroids.‚Å£
‚Å£
3. Asteroid moonlet Dimorphos as seen by the DART spacecraft 11 seconds before impact from a distance of 42 miles (68 km).‚Å£
‚Å£
4. The last complete image of asteroid moonlet Dimorphos, taken by the DRACO imager on DART from ~7 miles (12 km) from the asteroid and 2 seconds before impact. The image shows a patch of the asteroid that is 100 feet (31 m) across.‚Å£
‚Å£
5. DART‚Äôs final look at the asteroid moonlet Dimorphos before impact. The DRACO imager took this final image 4 miles (6 km) from the asteroid and one second before impact. The impact occurred during transmission of the image to Earth, resulting in a partial picture. The image shows a patch of the asteroid 51 feet (16 m) across.‚Å£
‚Å£
Credit: NASA/johnshopkinsapl‚Å£
‚Å£
#NASA #DARTMission #Space #Spacecraft #Asteroid #PlanetaryDefender #Space

post.author: nasa
post.title:
So nice, we captured it twice üî≠‚Å£
‚Å£
NASAWebb‚Äôs first infrared images are brought to new light with the addition of X-ray data from NASAChandraXray.‚Å£
‚Å£
Cartwheel Galaxy: The Cartwheel Galaxy got its shape from a collision with a smaller galaxy (outside the field) about 100 million years ago. X-rays seen by Chandra (blue and purple) come from superheated gas, exploded stars, and neutron stars and black holes pulling material from companion stars. Webb‚Äôs infrared view (red, orange, yellow, green, blue) shows the Cartwheel Galaxy plus 2 smaller companions (not part of the collision) against a backdrop of many more distant galaxies.‚Å£
‚Å£
Stephan's Quintet: 4 galaxies in Stephan‚Äôs Quintet are undergoing an intricate gravitational dance. (The 5th galaxy on the left is at a different distance!) Webb‚Äôs image (red, orange, yellow, green, blue) features never-seen-before details, like sweeping tails of gas and star formation bursts. Chandra (light blue) uncovers a shock wave that heats gas to tens of millions of degrees, as one galaxy passes through the others at around 2 million miles per hour. This image also includes infrared data from Spitzer (red, green, blue), now retired.‚Å£
‚Å£
Deep Field: Webb shows how a galaxy cluster, located ~4.2 billion light-years away, contains hundreds of galaxies. Galaxy clusters are filled with vast reservoirs of superheated gas seen only in X-ray light. Chandra data (blue) reveals gas with temperatures of tens of millions of degrees, possessing a total mass about 100 trillion times that of the Sun. Invisible dark matter forms an even larger fraction of the cluster‚Äôs total mass.‚Å£
‚Å£
Carina Nebula: Chandra‚Äôs data (pink) reveals over a dozen X-ray sources. These are mostly 1-2 million year old stars (very young for stars!) located in the outer region of a star cluster in the Carina Nebula. Young stars are much brighter in X-rays than old stars. The X-ray emission in the image‚Äôs top half likely comes from hot gas from the nebula‚Äôs 3 hottest, most massive stars, outside Webb‚Äôs view. Webb‚Äôs image uses: red, orange, yellow, green, cyan, and blue.‚Å£
‚Å£
Credit: X-ray-NASA/CXC/SAO; IR (Webb): NASA/ESA/CSA/STScI; IR (Spitzer): NASA/JPL-Caltech‚Å£
‚Å£
#NASA

post.author: nasa
post.title:
Total lunar eclipse of the heart ‚ù§Ô∏è‚Å£
‚Å£
On Tuesday, November 8, between 3:02 and 6:42 a.m. EST (0802-1350 UTC), a total lunar eclipse will occur, the last total lunar eclipse until March 14, 2025.‚Å£
‚Å£
A lunar eclipse occurs when the Sun, Earth, and Moon align, allowing the Moon to pass into Earth's shadow. In a total lunar eclipse, the entire Moon falls within the umbra ‚Äì the darkest part of Earth's shadow.‚Å£
‚Å£
During a lunar eclipse, light passes through our atmosphere before reaching the lunar surface, allowing colors of longer wavelengths, such as red and orange, to lightly illuminate its surface, while colors like blue and violet scatter across our planet.‚Å£
‚Å£
Image description:‚Å£
‚Å£
A composite photo shows the Moon in different stages of the eclipse from top left to bottom right. The Moon appears nearly full at the top left in the image before gradually becoming more obscured by Earth's shadow from the top left of the Moon. The skyline of Houston, Texas, can be seen in the distance.‚Å£
‚Å£
Credit: NASA/Norah Moran
‚Å£
#Eclipse #Moon #Space #Artemis

post.author: nasa
post.title:
Ring in the new year! ü™ê
 
We‚Äôre celebrating like it‚Äôs 1999‚Äîthe year that @NASAHubble captured this image of Saturn, the sixth planet from our Sun. 

Hubble took several photos of Saturn between 1996 and 2000, observing how its rings appear differently from our perspective as the gas giant makes its 29-year-long journey around the Sun. For instance, when Saturn‚Äôs rings are viewed from their edge on, they seem to be small and thin. However, when the planet‚Äôs orbit has moved enough that they can be viewed from an angle, the full picturesque breadth of Saturn‚Äôs iconic rings can be seen. 
 
The particles that make up Saturn‚Äôs rings mostly range from tiny, dust-sized icy grains to chunks as big as a house, with a few particles as large as mountains. Saturn's rings are thought to be pieces of comets, asteroids, or shattered moons that broke up before they reached the planet, torn apart by its powerful gravity. One of the most impressive sights in our solar system, Saturn continues to allure astronomers, with recent @NASAWebb observations targeting its largest moon Titan. Saturn has also been visited by four robotic missions‚Äîincluding our Cassini spacecraft, which dove into the planet's atmosphere in 2017.
 
Image Description: Saturn and its rings. The warm brown-and-creme hues of Saturn‚Äôs cloudy atmosphere present a gradient of color against the dark blackness of space. At its south pole, the darkest shades of the ombr√© pattern create a circle of earthy brown. Circling Saturn, grey rings are intersected by the Cassini Division, a gap measuring 2,920 miles (4,700 kilometers), which breaks up the otherwise halo-like rings. 
 
Credit: NASA and The Hubble Heritage Team (STScI/AURA); Acknowledgment: R.G. French (Wellesley College), J. Cuzzi (NASA/Ames), L. Dones (SwRI), and J. Lissauer (NASA/Ames)
 
#NASA #Space #NewYear #NewYearsEve #Saturn #Hubble #Telescope #Planet #SolarSystem

post.author: nasa
post.title:
The cold never bothered me anyway üßä‚Å£
‚Å£
Our Cassini spacecraft glimpsed Saturn's cold and icy moon Enceladus, whose frozen surface ice hides a deep ocean. Though it may look like rivers etch the surface of the small moon, the cracks covering the surface are believed to be from relatively warm sections in the crust, where ice water particles and gasses jet out continuously from the oceans below, contributing to Saturn's E ring. Some of these fissures may be hydrothermal vents that stretch down to its ocean.‚Å£
‚Å£
Enceladus is a small moon that orbits Saturn at a distance of 148,000 miles (238,000 km) in a tidally locked elliptical pattern ‚Äì the same side of Enceladus faces toward the planet, with an average temperature of -330 F¬∫ (-201 C¬∫). The average thickness of the icy shell is about 12 to 16 miles (20 to 25 km).‚Å£
‚Å£
In 2005, the Cassini spacecraft first examined the moon's south polar region, capturing its unique and complex terrain. Along the way, the spacecraft has deepened our understanding of the moon ‚Äì leading scientists to believe that Enceladus' chemistry, vast oceans, and internal heat ‚Äì make it a prime world to search for life beyond our planet.‚Å£
‚Å£
Image description: Cassini's image of the white surface of Enceladus is seen in an enhanced colored view. The moon's surface is marred by light blue cracks spreading out in all directions and spotted with deep craters. The planet is not fully visible as black space surrounds the moon, and a shadow envelops the right side of its surface.‚Å£
‚Å£
Credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech/Space Science Institute‚Å£
‚Å£
#Frozen #Space #Saturn #SolarSystem #Cassini #Oceans #Cold #Icy #NASA

post.author: nasa
post.title:
Save the dateüìç
‚Å£
The Moon‚Äôs shadow will cross the contiguous United States during a "ring of fire" annular eclipse on Oct. 14, 2023, and a total solar eclipse on April 8, 2024.‚Å£
‚Å£
Where will you be for these upcoming eclipses? Swipe to see our new map, which could help you decide. These eclipses offer a unique opportunity to study the sun's corona, the outermost part of the sun's atmosphere that is normally difficult to see without using special instruments.‚Å£
‚Å£
Whether you plan to travel to see the eclipse or watch it from your backyard, we hope you'll take a moment to appreciate the beauty and power of our nearest star. Anyone located in the annular eclipse path, from Oregon to Texas, will have a chance to see the annular eclipse if the skies are clear. Anyone located in the total eclipse path, from Texas to Maine, will have a chance to see the total eclipse, weather permitting. ‚Å£
‚Å£
Except during the brief total phase of a total solar eclipse, when the Moon completely blocks the Sun‚Äôs bright face, it is not safe to look directly at the Sun without specialized eye protection for solar viewing.‚Å£
‚Å£
Viewing any part of the bright Sun through a camera lens, binoculars, or a telescope without a special-purpose solar filter secured over the front of the optics will instantly cause severe eye injury.‚Å£
‚Å£
Image descriptions: ‚Å£
	‚Å£
An annular solar eclipse creates a "ring of fire" around the Moon, like that seen in this image taken by JAXA/NASA Hinode spacecraft. A black circle is surrounded by rays of orange light. Credit: JAXA/NASA/SAO/NAOJ‚Å£
	‚Å£
A total solar eclipse is seen on Monday, Aug. 21, 2017, above Madras, Oregon. A black circle is surrounded by rays of white light contrasting with the black sky. Credit: NASA/Aubrey Gemignani.‚Å£
	‚Å£
The left side of the continental US is picture with a path of the annular eclipse, as indicated by yellow circles. Credit: NASA/SVS/Michala Garrison; eclipse calculations by Ernie Wright, NASA Goddard‚Å£
	‚Å£
The right side of the continental US pictured with the path of the total eclipse as indicated through purple circles.‚Å£
‚Å£
#NASA #SolarEclipse #Eclipse #SaveTheDate #SkyWatchers #Sun #Moon #Skygazing

post.author: nasa
post.title:
Saturn is in its messy era ü™ê

Data from @NASAHubble, the @NASASolarsystem Cassini mission, and the twin Voyager spacecraft reveal that small sections of Saturn‚Äôs rings are falling into and heating its atmosphere.

The leading explanation is that icy ring particles raining down onto Saturn's atmosphere cause this heating. This could be due to the impact of micrometeorites, solar wind particle bombardment, solar ultraviolet radiation, or electromagnetic forces picking up electrically charged dust.

There is no cause for alarm though‚Äîalthough Saturn‚Äôs iconic rings are slowly falling they‚Äôve got another 100 million years of life in them. Ultimately, this unexpected interaction between Saturn and its rings could provide scientists with a tool for predicting if planets around other stars have glorious Saturn-like ring systems, too.

Image description: A image of Saturn as seen in near-ultraviolet by the Hubble Space Telescope. Saturn appears an ombre of blue and purple, its rings appearing much darker than the planet's body as they reflect much less ultraviolet sunlight. Above the rings and the dark equatorial region of Saturn, a bulge appears as an extended band of white that is 30 percent brighter than the surrounding light blue regions. It's believed that icy ring particles raining on the atmosphere cause atmospheric heating that makes the upper atmosphere reflect more ultraviolet sunlight in the bulge region. The poles of Saturn are bathed in white hues, caused by the thinner atmosphere in this region which also causes auroras. The background of this image is the blackness of space.

Credits: NASA, ESA, Lotfi Ben-Jaffel (IAP & LPL)

#NASA #Space #Jupiter #Rings #SolarSystem #Galaxy #Planet #Hubble #Saturn

post.author: nasa
post.title:
Wow, Uranus is showing off more these days.‚Å£
‚Å£
Peering beneath clouds of the ice giant ‚Äì Uranus ‚Äì scientists have seen strong evidence of a large polar cyclone at the planet‚Äôs north pole. Astronomers, using data from ground-based telescopes, looked deeper into Uranus‚Äô atmosphere than ever before, observing that air at the north pole seems drier and warmer, an indication of a strong cyclone.‚Å£
‚Å£
This new view of Uranus adds to the data that all planets in our solar system with a substantial atmosphere show signs of a swirling vortex at the poles. Our Voyager-2 spacecraft captured evidence of a cyclone at the planet‚Äôs other end, the south pole, when it passed by the ice giant in 1986.‚Å£
‚Å£
Image descriptions:‚Å£
‚Å£
Image 1: A microwave observation in wavelength band Ka shows Uranus in shades of blue and green, with the colors tinting lighter green toward the right side of the planet. Credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech/VLA‚Å£
‚Å£
Image 2: A microwave observation in wavelength band Q shows the ice giant in shades of blue, orange, and purple, with the colors tinting lighter orange toward the right side of the planet. Credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech/VLA‚Å£
‚Å£
Image 3: A microwave observation in wavelength band K shows the ice giant in shades of blue, black, and white, with the colors getting lighter toward the right side of the planet. Credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech/VLA‚Å£
‚Å£
Image 4: Voyager captures the full disk of Uranus which appears light-blue in the blackness of space, in the lower right portion of the planet, a faint white cloud appears. Credit: NASA‚Å£
‚Å£
#NASA #Space #SolarSystem #Gas #Uranus

post.author: nasa
post.title:
Of course Saturn brought its ring light ü™ê‚Å£
‚Å£
The James Webb Space Telescope took its first near-infrared look at Saturn on June 25. The planet appears extremely dark at this wavelength, as methane gas in its atmosphere absorbs sunlight ‚Äî but its rings stay bright!‚Å£
‚Å£
This image was taken as part of a Webb science program designed to test the telescope‚Äôs capacity to detect faint moons around the planet and study its bright rings. Take a closer look here to find details within the planet's ring system, as well as the moons Dione, Enceladus, and Tethys. Saturn‚Äôs rings are made up of an array of rocky and icy fragments ‚Äì the particles range in size from smaller than a grain of sand to a few as large as mountains on Earth.‚Å£
‚Å£
Learn more at the link in NASAWebb‚Äôs bio.‚Å£
‚Å£
Image descriptions:‚Å£
Two-part swipe through of a Webb image of Saturn, its rings and moons. The background is mostly dark. Saturn is seen as a dark orange-brown circle (split between the two images), surrounded by several blazing bright, thick, horizontal whiteish rings. There are three tiny dots on the left side of the first image. These are three of Saturn‚Äôs moons. From top to bottom, they are Dione, Enceladus, and Tethys, respectively. There is a slightly darker tint at the northern and southern poles of the planet. The rings surrounding Saturn are mostly broad, with a few singular narrow gaps between the broader rings. There is an innermost, thicker ring, and next to that is a brighter, wider ring. Traveling farther outward, there is a small dark gap before another thicker ring. In the thicker ring, there is a narrow faint band. There is then an outermost, faintest, thinnest ring.‚Å£
‚Å£
Credit: NASA, ESA, CSA, STScI, Matt Tiscareno (SETI Institute), Matt Hedman (University of Idaho), Maryame El Moutamid (Cornell University), Mark Showalter (SETI Institute), Leigh Fletcher (University of Leicester), Heidi Hammel (AURA). Image processing: J. DePasquale (STScI)‚Å£
‚Å£
 #JWST #JamesWebbSpaceTelescope #NASA #Saturn #Rings #Planets #Moons #SolarSystem #Space

post.author: nasa
post.title:
Look up tonight to see a full moon!

And not just any full moon: a supermoon, or a moon that's within 90% of perigee, its closest approach to Earth. This makes it slightly larger than the average full moon from our perspective‚Äîand though the difference is nearly indistinguishable to the human eye, we still think that a big, bright Moon is pretty super.

Though the Moon reached its peak on Monday, July 3, it should still appear full for the next couple of nights. This photo of the full moon was taken from the ISS by NASA astronaut Jeff Williams on Aug. 18, 2016. If you're interested in learning more about the Moon and its landmarks, visit our interactive Daily Moon Guide at go.nasa.gov/moonguide.

Image description: A bright, full moon, as seen from the International Space Station. The Moon hangs near the top-right corner of the image, with its lunar seas and other features clearly visible. Beneath it, Earth's cloudtops stretch across the bottom half of the photo at a slightly downward angle, with blue skies fading to black at the image's top border. Credit: NASA/Jeff Williams

#NASA #Space #Earth #Moon #MoonPhotography #Supermoon #SpaceStation #SpaceExploration

post.author: nasa
post.title:
Look up tonight to see a Super Blue Moon!‚Å£
‚Å£
August begins and ends with a full moon. When there are two full moons in a single calendar month, we call the second one a "blue moon." This doesn‚Äôt mean that the Moon will actually look blue, but it will still be worth checking out (weather permitting). But wait, there's more! The blue moon will also be a "supermoon," as it will be at its closest point to Earth and appear about 7% larger and brighter than an average full moon.‚Å£
‚Å£
This rare occurrence will peak at 9:36pm ET on Aug. 30 (0136 UTC on Aug. 31). Keep your eyes on the sky for this trifecta of labels being applied to the Moon which only occurs about every 10 years on average.‚Å£
‚Å£
Image description: A bright supermoon is seen at the center of the image. Craters are shown on the center and most of the left side of the Moon appearing to be a darker shade of gray. The supermoon stands out against the darkness of space. Taken on Aug. 10, 2014, in Washington.‚Å£
‚Å£
Credit: NASA/Bill Ingalls‚Å£
‚Å£
#Moon #SuperMoon #FullMoon #SkyWatching #NASA #Space #astronomy #BlueMoon

post.author: nasa
post.title:
Here‚Äôs lookin at you kid ü™ê‚Å£
‚Å£
Our Cassini spacecraft captured this image from about 746,000 miles (1.2 million kilometers) using red, green, and blue filters to create this natural-color view of Saturn. Cassini not only captured the gas giant but also some world photobombers with Venus, Mars, Earth, and Earth‚Äôs Moon visible as small dots of light.‚Å£
‚Å£
Saturn, the sixth planet from the Sun, will be visible each day at sunset until Feb. 2024, appearing like a bright yellowish ‚Äústar‚Äù on the southeastern horizon.‚Å£
‚Å£
In the first image, Venus appears as a bright white dot in the upper left. Mars is diagonally above Venus and appears as a faint red dot. Earth and the Moon appear in the second image as a pale blue dot and a smaller dot to the lower right. Cassini was not the first to see Saturn up close: Pioneer 11, a spacecraft that helped pave the way for exploring the solar system, first studied Saturn 44 years ago.‚Å£
‚Å£
Image descriptions:‚Å£
‚Å£
Image 1: Half of Saturn appears outlined by bright sunlight that highlights its rings, which unfurl out to the left at various distances from the planet. Small dots in blue, white, and red represent moons and planets.‚Å£
‚Å£
Image 2: Half of Saturn appears outlined by bright sunlight that highlights its rings, which unfurl out to the right at various distances from the planet. Small dots of blue, white, and yellow represent moons and planets.‚Å£
‚Å£
Image 3: A whole view of the same image, with annotations showing the locations of Venus, Mars, the Moon, and Earth.‚Å£
‚Å£
Credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech/SSI‚Å£
‚Å£
#NASA #Saturn #Earth #Moon #Venus #Mars #Casablanca #Cassini #SolarSystem

post.author: nasa
post.title:
The trail we blaze‚Å£
‚Å£
@NASAHubble catches a cosmic reef 163,000 light-years from Earth in the constellation Dorado. These nebulae are part of a vast star-forming region, the Large Magellanic Cloud, a satellite galaxy of the Milky Way full of massive stars.‚Å£
‚Å£
The stars near the center of the image are around 10 to 20 times the size of our Sun, and their intense radiation heats surrounding dense gases like oxygen seen in light blue to 20,000¬∞F (11,000¬∞C). Hydrogen and nitrogen are relatively cooler in temperature and are seen in red. The nebula in the lower left was created from a star 200,000 times brighter than our Sun, which ejected gas in a series of eruptive events.‚Å£
‚Å£
Image description: An image is split in two. In the bottom left of the first image a bright blue ring appears, slightly fading in all directions, with a small blue dot in the middle. Red and orange waves of gas ripple, arcing from top left to top right. A light blue center appears out of the sea of red, and several bright white dots shine through. In the top right, dark blue gas emanates from the blackness of space.‚Å£
‚Å£
Credit: NASA, ESA, STScI‚Å£
‚Å£
#Space #Nebula #Stars #CosmicReef #NASA #Hubble

post.author: nasa
post.title:
Opposites attract.‚Å£
‚Å£
All eyes are on Jupiter after reaching opposition, which occurs when the planet and the Sun are on opposite sides of the sky. Captured here in ultraviolet wavelengths, @NASAHubble views the gas giant in hues of blue, pink, and purple, invisible to the human eye. Scientists use ultraviolet wavelengths to further study Jupiter‚Äôs storm systems, mapping deep water clouds that define Jupiter‚Äôs atmosphere.‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£
Clouds on stormy Jupiter are far taller than scientists predicted, with some dipping 60 miles (100 km) below the cloud tops ‚Äì the iconic Great Red Spot (here in ultraviolet blue) extends over 200 miles (350 km) below its highest peaks.‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£
Image description: The planet Jupiter with its cloud bands seen in shades of pink, rusty red, blue, and purple. The Great Red Spot is a deep navy blue, surrounded by bands and swirls of pink, and light blue.‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£
Credit: NASA, ESA, and M. Wong (University of California - Berkeley); Processing: Gladys Kober (NASA/Catholic University of America)‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£
#Hubble #NASA #Jupiter #SolarSystem #Space #Ultraviolet

post.author: nasa
post.title:
A little star cluster hauling a Christmas tree. üéÑ‚Å£
‚Å£
Discovered about 2,500 light-years from Earth, the Christmas Tree Cluster is a bundle of young stars, most about 1 to 5 million years old. (For comparison, our Sun has been burning for 5 *billion* years.)‚Å£
‚Å£
These stars give off X-rays that were picked up by our orbiting NASAChandraXRay observatory, and are depicted here in various shades of blue and white. They‚Äôre surrounded by a nebula of gas observed by other telescopes, shown here in green, giving this cluster (officially known as NGC 2264) its memorable nickname.‚Å£
‚Å£
Image description: A triangle of green gas, resembling a Christmas tree, is filled with blue and white stars that look like Christmas ornaments. Other stars and astronomical phenomena fill the background of the image.‚Å£
‚Å£
Credit: X-ray: NASA/CXC/SAO; Optical: T.A. Rector (NRAO/AUI/NSF and NOIRLab/NSF/AURA) and B.A. Wolpa (NOIRLab/NSF/AURA); Infrared: NASA/NSF/IPAC/CalTech/Univ. of Massachusetts; Image Processing: NASA/CXC/SAO/L. Frattare & J. Major‚Å£
‚Å£
#NASA #Space #Astronomy #Astrophotography #ChristmasTree #ChristmasDecor #RedTruckChristmas

post.author: nasa
post.title:
If you like it, put a ring on it üíç‚Å£
‚Å£
Saturn is not the only planet in our solar system with rings, but its rings are the most prominent, extending 175,000 miles (282,000 kilometers) from the planet. The rings are likely made of chunks of ice and rock ranging in size from dust-sized grains to house-sized pieces, composed of the remnants of comets, asteroids, and moons shredded by Saturn‚Äôs powerful gravity.‚Å£
‚Å£
This engaging view of Saturn was captured by our Cassini spacecraft in 2008 from a distance of 690,000 miles (1.1 million km). Six of Saturn‚Äôs moons appear throughout the image, including Titan and Enceladus, two of the most promising worlds to look for life beyond Earth.‚Å£
‚Å£
Image description: An image split in two shows Saturn‚Äôs rings extending to the far left of the image, partially obscured by shadow, with the planet appearing striped in shades of yellow, tan, and blue. Saturn‚Äôs moons appear as small dots in gray and white across the image.‚Å£
‚Å£
Credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech/Space Science Institute‚Å£
‚Å£
#Cassini #Space #Saturn #NASA #Ring #SolarSystem

post.author: nasa
post.title:
It‚Äôs the side of the Moon we never see from home: the far side.‚Å£
‚Å£
Often incorrectly called the ‚Äúdark side‚Äù of the Moon ‚Äì incorrect because it receives equal amounts of sunlight as the near side does ‚Äì the Moon‚Äôs far side has stark characteristics. To start, it‚Äôs more heavily cratered and has fewer maria, or large, dark, basaltic plains created by early volcanic eruptions. They‚Äôre called maria because that‚Äôs the Latin word for ‚Äúseas.‚Äù Early astronomers thought the dark areas were oceans.‚Å£
‚Å£
So why can‚Äôt we see it from Earth? The same side of the Moon always faces us because the Moon is tidally locked to our planet. That means the Moon‚Äôs orbital period is the same duration as its spin around its axis. It takes a whole month on Earth for the Moon to turn once.‚Å£
‚Å£
Image description: The round, gray disc of the Moon is pockmarked across its surface with craters of all sizes. This mosaic of the Moon‚Äôs far side is comprised of 15,000 images taken by our Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter between November 2009 and February 2011.‚Å£
‚Å£
Credits: NASA/GSFC/Arizona State University‚Å£
‚Å£
#Moon #Luna #Mosaic #WishYouWereHere #NASA

post.author: nasa
post.title:
Did the Moon make you do it? üåä ‚Å£
 ‚Å£
Walking along a beach you may see seashells, driftwood and seaweed left by the retreating tides at your feet. Look up at the Moon, and you‚Äôre seeing the main cause of the surge and retreat of oceans from our shores. As distant as the Moon may seem, its gravitational pull on Earth plays a huge role in the formation of tides.‚Å£
 ‚Å£
As the tide rolls in or out, what you‚Äôre really seeing is a cycle of small changes to the distribution of our planet‚Äôs oceans. As the Moon‚Äôs gravity tugs at Earth, it shifts Earth‚Äôs mass, distorting its shape ever so slightly into that of a football ‚Äï elongated at the equator and shortened at the poles. This effect on the solid Earth can be detected by scientific instruments, but we can watch the same changes to Earth‚Äôs oceans just by visiting the beach.‚Å£
 ‚Å£
Image description: The waning gibbous Moon is pictured from the International Space Station as it orbited 262 miles above the Swiss Alps. The Moon is surrounded by the blackness of space, as it floats above the blue glow of Earth‚Äôs atmosphere. Earth‚Äôs surface appears shrouded by clouds.‚Å£
 ‚Å£
Credit: NASA‚Å£
 ‚Å£
#NASA #Space #Moon #HighTide #Lowtide #Tides #Lunar #Earth #Water #Beach
